Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Endothelial Dysfunction in Single-Ventricle Congenital Heart Disease

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: Participants included SV-CHD patients eligible for surgical palliation.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received standard surgical and pharmacological treatment, while the control group received standard care without targeted endothelial interventions.

Objective.evidence: To assess the effect of targeted interventions on endothelial dysfunction in SV-CHD patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in endothelial function, measured by flow-mediated dilation, over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant improvement in endothelial function (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
